The same indefatigable friend, Mr. Payne, was requested by the ExecutivB
Committee to attend as a Delegate in the Convention at Austin, on the 22n?
of November; and also to communicate with the Governor and Legislature of
Texas, in regard to the extension of our road through that State. The Coa..-
mittee's opinion of the distinguished ability wherewith he accomplished hjgj
mission, would best appear from the fact, that, on his return, the thanks ofthft
Coinmittce were publicly tendered to him, and his Address ordered to be pule
lished in all the city papers. Mr. C. handed in a copy of Mr. Paynb'j
Address, and referred to him for a more detailed account of his delicate
mission.
Mr. Cohen stated that this Committee also established an office, where the
maps, books and papers referring to this road, and railroad documents generally,
were collected, and where the friends of this enterprise might repair U
information.
The meetings of the Committee were held on Monday of each week, since
-Juno last, at that office ; and it was designed as part of a system of bureaus
to be established throughout the Parishes, and the germ of a more extended
organization.
The proceedings of the Convention in June last, which gave form and
vitality to the entcrprize, had been printed in pamphlet form, and distributed
as widely as possible.
The Executive Committee also requested their Secretary, Mr. B. F.
Flanders, to prepare an abstract of the Committee's proceedings, and forward
the same to the members of the Permanent Committee, in pamphlet form-
This he accomplished promptly and well. Mr. C. handed in a copy of saial
abstract, which, he said, brought our proceedings down to the 8th day «
December last.
With regard to surveys, owing to causes which are explained in the abstract,
and which were beyond the control of the Committee, they were unable to
place Surveyors in the field until the first week of December.
To insure the completion, before the 2nd day of January, of the survey
from New Orleans to Berwick's Bay, two surveying parties were set to w<&*
on different sections. It was the opinion of the Committee, which w*3
concurred in by Judge Moore, who happened to be here on his way to
Washington, that the only portion of the contemplated line to Opelousas, »
which there was any uncertainty as to feasibility or cost, was that lying between
the Mississippi river and Berwick's Bay, and that the necessary omission of *
survey beyond the latter point, would, under the circumstances, cause A
